NewsLine.NewsLineText: CONGO-DEMOCRATIC-HUNGER (PICTURES):Rwanda pull-out from Congo may worsen aid problems

body.p: By Matthew Green

GOMA, Congo, Sept 23 (Reuters) - Rwanda's pull-out from Congo risks enflaming an already desperate humanitarian crisis as armed groups battle for control in the resulting power vacuum, aid workers said on Monday.
Rwanda began withdrawing troops last week under a peace deal aimed at ending a four-year war that has already killed an estimated two million people, mainly through starvation and disease.

Gun battles between rebels and tribal warriors erupted hours after Rwandans left the town of Kindu, a sign that the retreat of the war's most disciplined force might disrupt relief work by unleashing fresh mayhem.
"The situation is already tragic, but it could get even worse," said Bernard Leflaive, Congo country manager for the Merlin emergency medical relief charity.
"The sudden withdrawal by the Rwandans creates a vacuum for instability," he told Reuters in the eastern Congolese city of Goma, a hub for aid operations.
Rwanda, pursuing a relentless quest for security following its 1994 genocide, invaded the Democratic Republic of Congo to neutralise militia who fled there after conducting the massacres.
Rwandan President Paul Kagame agreed to withdraw under a July peace deal with Congolese President Joseph Kabila, who has pledged to disarm the Rwandan rebels in return.

But while Rwanda has surprised many in the region by apparently beginning to pull out its troops, there has been virtually no progress in disarming a host of militia groups murdering, raping and pillaging in eastern Congo.
The war has forced hundreds of thousands to flee their homes, while many others are too scared to venture into their fields to farm, crippling agriculture in a one-time tropical breadbasket.

Fearing an outbreak of violence when the Rwandans left, Merlin evacuated international staff from Kindu ahead of the pull-out, removing workers providing the only access to medical care for most of the 140,000 inhabitants.
SHOOT OUT IN MAIN STREET

Aid workers are watching to see whether the Kindu scenario -- where "Mai Mai" tribal fighters traded gunfire in a main street with Rwandan-backed rebels on Thursday -- will be repeated in other areas.

"I'm sure that with this security situation we will lose access to most of our beneficiaries," said Jean-Charles Dei, eastern Congo coordinator for the World Food Programme, the emergency food aid arm of the United Nations. "There will be a humanitarian tragedy soon if something is not done urgently."
The U.N. has only enough resources to feed 200,000 people in the east of the country out of 800,000 in desperate need, Dei said.
The threat of ambush makes road travel impossible in many areas, putting a premium on food drops by a flotilla of ageing cargo planes criss-crossing the jungle canopy.
If the militia havoc worsens, preventing relief workers from landing at bush airstrips, then an even smaller proportion of the needy will receive help.
Rwanda is handing over control to its Congolese allies, the RCD rebel movement, whose ill-disciplined, unpaid troops are unlikely to deliver as much security as Rwanda.
Young rebels in camouflage fatigues carrying battered AK-47 rifles are a common sight at remote grass airfields, but they provide little comfort to pilots.

"We're very worried about the impact this quick withdrawal could have on the humanitarian situation," said Jean-Charles Dupin, U.N. humanitarian coordinator for North Kivu, one of the areas worst affected by the war.
"We're very concerned about whether the RCD's army will be able to fill the gap, and give guarantees to humanitarian actors."
